repnme.cdata!:
India - Uttar Pradesh Fiscal Reform and
            Public Sector Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory
            and project sustainability is likely. world Bank performance
            is satisfactory based on the ratings for lending and
            outcomes. Borrower performance is satisfactory based on the
            ratings of project preparation, implementation, and
            outcomes. Lessons learned include the following points:
            Programmatic adjustment lending to selected states of India
            can be an effective instrument for supporting fiscal reforms
            at the state level. When policy formulation and reform
            implementation capacity is weak, as in the case of Uttar
            Pradesh, a more strategic design can lead to a more focused
            but deeper dialogue. Detailed listing and auditing of a
            subset of line items within the expenditure budget,
            identified as High Priority Development Expenditures, tends
            to create a "budget within a budget"--a better
            approach would encourage reprioritization within the budget,
            in the context of an improved budget process, while avoiding
            micro-management. In establishing an effective poverty and
            social monitoring system, emphasis should be placed from the
            outset on a) institutionalizing a system of periodic
            collection and analysis of data; and b) fostering demand for
            the use of such data, both within and outside the government.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Uttar Pradesh Fiscal Reform and
            Public Sector Restructuring Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Uttar Pradesh Fiscal Reform and
            Public Sector Restructuring Project, will aim at reversing
            the government's unsuccessful reforms, and will
            support: 1) fiscal reforms, ensuring its sustainability,
            through the creation of additional fiscal pressures over the
            medium term, for public investments in high priority
            development areas, including improvements in the social
            sector spending; and, 2) public sector restructuring, with
            the intent to improve the quality of service delivery. This
            will be achieved by transforming the role of Government,
            through civil service reforms, which will prod transparency,
            deregulation, and will strengthen anti-corruption
            institutions, through decentralization, and improved
            financial management, and accountability. The credit/loan
            will be disbursed in one tranche, being the first operation
            within a proposed sequence of operations. Improved fiscal
            adjustments, and social services delivery, are benefits
            which will prod economic growth, while reducing poverty, in
            addition to the beneficial contributions in the overall
            reduction of public sector borrowing requirements. However,
            the possible reverse in the reform agenda due to political
            opposition, and, the weak institutional capacity, are major
            risks to be taken into consideration.
